TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , was a stateless person who had been born in DATE and until his death on DATE lived in PERSON . The applicant is represented before the ORG by PERSON and PERSON A. PERSON , lawyers practising in PERSON . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr V. Grosu .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Registrar was informed of the applicant ’s death . On DATE the applicant ’s son , PERSON , informed the PERSON that he wanted the proceedings to continue and wished to participate in them , retaining the applicant ’s lawyers as his representatives . For practical reasons , Mr PERSON will continue to be referred to in this decision as “ the applicant ” , although PERSON is now to be regarded as having this status ( see the PERSON v. GPE CARDINAL DATE , § CARDINAL , Series A no . CARDINAL-C ) .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant was accused of consuming narcotic drugs while serving a sentence . On DATE ORG discontinued the criminal proceedings against him and ordered his immediate release .

CARDINAL . After leaving the court building the applicant was arrested again by the police . The reason was that he had been found walking in the street without documents and had no permanent abode or means of support . The applicant then gave personal details , including his permanent address in PERSON , to a police officer . He indicated that he did not have any identity documents , which were all still with the prison administration .
CARDINAL . The applicant was placed in a centre for homeless people ( “ the Centre ” ) . His lawyers complained that he had been detained unlawfully .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyers made a complaint of unlawful detention to ORG . The court postponed CARDINAL hearings ( on DATE and DATE ) at the request of the applicant ’s lawyers , who had asked for documents concerning the reasons for the applicant ’s arrest from the prosecution .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant signed an authority form for his lawyers to represent him before the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE it became clear that he was no longer at the FAC . A criminal investigation was opened against CARDINAL officers , who were accused of taking the applicant out of the LOC during TIME of DATE to a place on the outskirts of PERSON , from where he had fled . At the same time , the applicant was declared a wanted person .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG found that the applicant ’s arrest and detention had been unlawful since none of the legal grounds cited by the prosecution applied . The court relied expressly on Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention . That decision was final .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was expelled from GPE at the border with GPE , even though his extradition to GPE had been refused by the ORG on DATE . On DATE he was arrested when crossing the border with GPE .

CARDINAL . Following his arrest the applicant was placed in the detention facility of ORG of ORG ( “ the DSO ” ) . On DATE his lawyers complained to ORG that the PERSON administration had refused to allow him to receive any food or clothes . They noted that he was suffering from hepatitis and required a special diet and that there was a risk of deterioration of his state of health . They asked for their client to be transferred to prison no . CARDINAL so that he could obtain appropriate medical treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyers complained to ORG , noting the risk to his state of health in the inhuman conditions of detention of the GPE detention facility . On DATE the applicant was transferred to prison no . CARDINAL in PERSON .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyers asked the authorities at prison no . CARDINAL to inform them of the reasons for placing their client in a solitary cell . On DATE they were informed that upon his arrival the applicant had been placed in solitary confinement for DATE , in order for him to undergo examinations aimed at establishing the state of his health and for medical treatment to be prescribed if found to be necessary . On DATE the applicant was transferred to an ordinary cell .

CARDINAL . In TIME of DATE CARDINAL detainees who shared the cell with the applicant alerted the prison guards that he was not showing any signs of life . Thereafter the prison doctor pronounced the applicant dead .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE a medical expert examined the applicant ’s body . He found that the cause of death had been cardiac - pulmonary deficiency which had been caused by ischemic cardiopathy and pulmonary fibrocavital tuberculosis . The medical expert also found marks on the cadaver ’s back which were interpreted as light injuries caused while the applicant was alive . He was also found to have been under the influence of a minor degree of alcohol intoxication at the time of his death .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyers informed the ORG of their client ’s death .

CARDINAL . On DATE a ORG Office prosecutor decided not to initiate a criminal investigation in the absence of any evidence that a crime had been committed . The prosecutor referred to the statements made by the applicant ’s cellmates and the head of the detention block in which he had died . He also cited the findings of the medical and toxicology experts and relied on video recordings , which showed that nobody had entered or left the cell during TIME . He noted the presence of marks on the cadaver ’s back , without making any comment in that respect .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyers asked ORG to revoke the decision of DATE . They mentioned , inter alia , that important questions had not been answered during the preliminary investigation , such as whether their client ’s life could have been saved had he been correctly diagnosed and treated in prison no . CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG replied that the decision of DATE had been taken correctly .
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s lawyers challenged the decisions of DATE and DATE before ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the complaint , on the ground that it had not established that any breaches of fundamental rights had occurred . One of the applicant ’s lawyers was present at the hearing . That decision was final .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s son expressed his wish to continue with the case lodged by his father and raised in essence a complaint under LAW concerning the incompletely established circumstances of his father ’s death .
